Regulation of the transcription factor NF-kappaB involves proteasome - mediated processing of the <extra_id_0> NF-kappaB1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> <extra_id_0> p105 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> precursor protein , which generates the <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> subunit of NF-kappaB .

The processing of <extra_id_0> p105 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> occurs constitutively in vivo but can be markedly enhanced by various cellular activation agents , although the underlying regulatory mechanism is not yet clear .

In the present study , we demonstrate that signal - mediated induction of <extra_id_0> p105 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> processing in human T cells is associated with de novo synthesis of this precursor protein .

Transient transfection studies performed in COS7 cells revealed that the newly synthesized <extra_id_0> p105 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein appears to be more rapidly processed compared to its accumulated form that is already associated with the processed product <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
